div.p: S91/11070 unit 437, VPRS 3992/P inward registered correspondence, VA 475 Chief Secretary's Department, Public Record Office, Victoria.

I have the honor to solicit, that you will take into kind consideration my particular wish of being allowed to remain in the position of Governm. Botanist also after the end of this year, altho' I have attained the age of 66,
See also M to H. Moors, 22 June 1891; T. Wilson to M, 17 December 1891; and M to T. Wilson, 17 December 1891 (in this edition as 91-12-17a). — for the following reasons.

1, The Department , which I administrate, was created by myself , and this at a time, when it could not be foreseen, that tenor
tenure? of office might depend on age; hence I gave as a free
donation my very extensive private botanic collections , accumulated during early studies and travels, over to the Department.
2, I sunk in the course of years nearly all I had of worldly means disinterestedly into the establishment.

3, I am eager, to finish
the various great
works , in which under the auspices of the Government I am engaged for elaboration, and on which my long experiences in the field
and
my expertness in professional speciality I would like to bring yet, unimpaired in my action and resources, my knowledge to bear.
4, My eyesight and mental faculties are still good , so that the service will not suffer on that account.

5, May I flatter myself, that my work under the Government has promoted extensively the rural resources of the colony , has brought before the general world many of its capabilities in a prominent manner, and has so far shed some additional lustre on the colony .

6, My position, may I say, is quite exceptional
in the
service , and my ceding from the post prematurely, would necessarily car[ry]
cut off on p/c check MS.
with it humiliation before t[he]
cut off on p/c check MS.
science-world!

7, As moreover no one in the public service of Victoria could perform all the duties, carried out by me, and as no one is waiting therefore to fill my position , I trust my solicitation, will be kindly met to remain in office, somewhat longer, as even any leading European scientist, if called here, would need, to travel for many years , ere he could have a full insight into the native Flora and our climatic and rural conditions.

Grateful for former favors of the Government, and hopeful, that I also shall again experience the generous considerations of the public Service Commissioners,
On 20 November 1891 a minute on the file instructed that a copy of this letter be typed for the Chief Secretary to take to Cabinet. On 7 December the Under Secretary, T. Wilson, instructed that it be sent with his memorandum dated 7 December: 'Memo for the information of the Honorable the Chief Secretary. Baron von Mueller, the Government Botanist, and Mr Hayter, the Government Statist, who are each over sixty five years of age, have, by Order in Council under the Public Service Act, been continued in the performance of their duties until the 31st instant. In writing, by direction, to the Honorable the Premier on the 27th June 1890, recommending the continuance of the services of those gentlemen I stated as follows: — "In support of the retention of Baron Von Mueller and Mr Hayter, I have the honor to state that in my opinion it is necessary, in the interests of the Public Service, to retain their services as their duties cannot be performed by any officer who is due for promotion. Moreover it is essential that Mr Hayter should supervise the important work of taking the Census next year." For the same reasons those officers have since, from time to time, been required by Order in Council, to continue in the discharge of their respective duties. I beg now to attach a copy of a communication from Baron Von Mueller [i.e. the letter above] and to state that on the 3rd January 1890, the Chief Secretary approved of Mr Hayter's continuing to discharge his duties until the completion of the work connected with the Census of 1891. I should mention that the Census for 1881 and for 1891 was taken in April each year, and that Mr Hayter's report on the former, copy enclosed, was not completed until June 1883' (R91/11372, unit 663, VPRS 3992/P, Public Record Office, Victoria). On McLean's orders, Wilson forwarded this memorandum to the Premier on 8 December, minuting: 'In forwarding this memorandum to the Honable the Premier with a view to its transmission to the Public Service Board I beg to state that in my opinion it is necessary in the interests of the Public Secretary that the Officers therein mentioned be required to continue in the discharge of their respective duties'.
M's tenure was extended until 31 March 1892; see T. Wilson to M, 31 December 1891.
Enclosed with MS is a typescript copy of M to T. Wilson, 18 January 1892 (in this edition as 92-01-18a).
